metadata.title: Netflix and Chill: Building a Recommendation System in Excel | by Dave Smith | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Netflix and Chill: Building a Recommendation System in Excel
metadata.description: Step-by-step spreadsheets that teach you how to build a recommendation system in Excel. Discover the machine learning magic behind the binge.

all_paragraphs: With infinite shelf space on the internet, finding what you want to watch can be exhausting. Fortunately, combating decision fatigue is Netflix’s job…and they’re good at it. Too good at it.
They magically recommend you the perfect movie so your eyes stay glued to the tube and they turn your procrastination into a weekend binger on the couch.
Damn you, Netflix. What’s your secret? How do you know us so well?

The “magic” is surprisingly simple and the secrets are revealed in this tutorial using step-by-step spreadsheets you can download in Excel (recommended) or Google Sheets (calcs are slower; missing 1 graph due to compatibility) and follow along with to excellerate your learning:

Despite a wealth of papers or videos on recommender systems since the Netflix Prize competition, most are either (A) too technical to be accessible for beginners or (B) too high level to be practical.

In this post, we’ll build a movie recommender system from scratch with plain English explanations and step-by-step formulas you can follow in Excel. All gradient descent derivations are worked out by hand and you can use Excel drop-down filters to fine tune the model’s hyper-parameters and boost your intuition.
After a brief intro on recommendation systems, I’ll walk through the 4 parts below as we build a model to predict movie ratings for a handful of Hollywood stars.

I’ll explain the step-by-step math behind the machine learning magic and you can follow real numbers plugged into the formulas used in batch gradient descent (no “macros” or “Excel Solver” to hide the details).

A special thanks to Jeremy Howard and Rachel Thomas at Fast.AI. The spreadsheets here were inspired from their lesson on collaborative filtering (see the code here). The spreadsheets they present rely on Excel’s built-in solver to do the optimization calculations behind the scenes; whereas, the spreadsheets I built show each step of the gradient descent calculations and allow you to fine tune the model’s hyperparameters.
If the spreadsheets help you, consider signing up for my email list by clicking below and I’ll send you more spreadsheets that help you get started in machine learning and build neural nets.
Movie recommender systems can be simplified into to 2 broad classifications:
Is based on the idea of similar behaviors.

If Ross and Rachel have liked similar things in the past, let’s take some of Rachel’s favorite movies that Ross hasn’t seen and recommend them to him. Think of them as “taste doppelgangers” who “collaborate” with another to filter through all the noise on internet’s shelves. 2 users are deemed “similar” if their ratings have a strong correlation with another and the ratings can be implicit or explicit:
There are 2 types of collaborative filtering: neighborhood methods and latent factor models (a form of matrix factorization). The focus of this post is on a latent factor model called SVD++.
Is based on the idea of playing matchmaker.
Using the explicit tags (genre, actors, etc.) from content you’ve liked in the past, Netflix recommends new content to you which has similar tags.
Collaborative filtering (CF) is the hands-down winner vs. content-based filtering in movie recommenders when the dataset is large enough.
While there are countless hybrids and variations between these 2 broad classes, when the CF model is good enough, it turns out that adding metadata doesn’t help at all which is kinda mind blowing.

There is a large gap between what people say they like (user preferences, surveys, etc.) and their behavior. It’s best to let people’s viewing behavior speak for itself. (TIP: For better Netflix recommendations, scrub your “Viewing Activity” on Netflix and remove items you didn’t like by clicking here.)

In 2009, Netflix awarded $1MM to a team of researchers who developed an algorithm that improved Netflix’s prediction accuracy by 10%. While the winning algorithm was actually an ensemble of over 100 algorithms, SVD++ (a type of collaborative filtering) was 1 of the key algorithms that contributed most of the gains and is still used in production.

The SVD++ model (“Singular Value Decomposition approximate”) we’ll build is similar to the ideas first presented in an infamous blog post by Simon Funk in 2006 at the beginning of the Netflix competition. After the success of SVD++, virtually all Netflix competitors used it in their entries.
Simple, yet powerful. Let’s dig in.
The blog post model uses 30 fictitious ratings (5 users x 6 movies) to simplify the tutorial.

The Fast.AI lesson uses 225 real ratings (which is tough to illustrate in a blog post) based on the 15 most watched movies and the 15 most active users. With the exception of fake ‘user names’, the ratings data is from MovieLens.
We’ll use 25 ratings to train our model and 5 ratings to test the model’s accuracy.
Our goal is to build a system that works well on the 25 known ratings (training data) and hope it predicts well on the 5 hidden (but known) ratings (test data).
If we had more data, we’d split our data into 3 groups — training (~70%), validation (~20%), and test (~10%) and we would use our validation set to validate our model.
The rating prediction is a matrix multiplication or “dot product” of the user/movie features + user bias + movie bias.

A user bias is how harsh or nice the movie critic is. If the average rating of all movies on Netflix is a 3.5 and the average of everything you rate is a 4.0, you would have a 0.5 bias. Movie bias can be thought of the same way. If the Titanic had an average rating of 4.25 across all users, it would have a 0.75 bias (= 4.25–3.50).
RMSE = Root Mean Squared Error
RMSE is a number that attempts to answer the question “on average, how many stars (1–5) did your predicted ratings differ vs. the actual ratings”?
The lower the RMSE, the better the predictions…
In the spreadsheet, there are drop-down filters for 3 inputs. You should play around with each of these inputs and look at the impact they have on your errors.
Now, let’s watch the magic as the model starts off with random weights and learns the optimal ones.
Watching gradient descent in action feels like you’re watching a David Blaine magic trick.
You’re left in awe at the end and you want to learn how the trick was done. I’ll show you the trick in 2 steps and then reveal the math behind the magic.
At the start of training, weights are randomly assigned to the user/movie features and then the algorithm learns the optimal weights during training.
To demonstrate how seemingly “crazy” it is that we can randomly guess numbers and then let the computer learn the best numbers, below is a comparison of 2 weight initialization approaches:
Look at what happens to the RMSE training error from the start (epoch 0) to end (epoch 50) as the model learns the optimal values during training for both approaches:
As you can see below, both weight initialization approaches converge to a similar “error” at the end of training (0.12 vs. 0.17), but the “Kaiming He” approach converges to the lower error faster.
Key Take-Away: Regardless of which weights we started with, the machine learned good values over time!
Note: To experiment with other initial weights, go to sheet “hyperparameters_and_initial_wts” and type in your own values in cells G3-J7 and N3-Q8. Any weights between -1 and 1 should work.
To learn more about Kaiming He’s initialization, see below; otherwise, skip to Part 3 to learn the math behind the learning algorithm.
Now, it’s time to get nerdy and walk through the gradient descent math step by step.
Skip to PART 4 if you don’t want to really know how the magic works.
Gradient descent is the iterative algorithm used during training to update the values of movie features, user preferences, and biases for better predictions.
Step 1 — Define a cost/loss function to minimize and initialize weights
Step 3 — Calculate gradients (change in cost with respect to each weight)
Step 4 — Update each weight “justttt a little bit” (the learning rate) in the direction that will minimize the cost
To follow along as we update “user feature 1” for Tina Fey, go to sheet “training” and see rows 11–16.

Since we have a small data set, we’ll use batch gradient descent. This means we train the algorithm using the whole data set (all movies for 1 user in our example) instead of iterating 1 sample at a time like stochastic gradient descent (1 movie for 1 user in our example) which is faster when you have a large data set.
Using the formula below, our goal is to find the values of the latent factors (matrices U and M) which minimize the SSE (sum of squared errors) plus a L2 weight penalty to help the model generalize.
Below is the cost function calc in our Excel model. This calculation ignores the 1/2 terms as they are only used during gradient descent to make the math easier:

We add the weight penalty (L2 regularization or “ridge regression”) to prevent the latent factors from becoming too high. This ensures the model isn’t “over-fitting” (i.e. memorizing) the training data because it won’t perform well on the un-seen test movies.
Earlier, we trained the model using zero L2 regularization penalty and the RMSE training error was 0.12 after 50 epochs.
But how did the model perform vs. the test data?
If we change the L2 penalty factor from 0.000 to 0.300, our model should generalize better on the unseen test data:
Using the random initial weights, we’ll calculate Tina’s movie predictions. We ignore Titanic because it is part of our test data and not in our training data.
The goal is to find the gradient (“slope”) of the error with respect to the weight you are updating.

After finding the gradient, you can move that weight “justttt a little bit” as it “descends” in the opposite direction of the gradient and after you do this for each weight, you should have a lower cost the next training epoch.
“Justttt a little bit” is your learning rate and it is used in step 3 below after you’ve found the gradient.
Note: The above calcs can be seen in cells X11-X16 on sheet “training” per below.
If you explore the Excel calcs, you can see how the movie features and user/movie biases are updated in a similar manner.
After each training epoch, all movie/user features and biases are updated simultaneously and the training cycle repeats itself.
Now that we’ve trained the model, let’s visualize 2 of the movies’ latent factors to gain some insight.

If our model was more complex and it had 10, 20, or 50+ latent factors, we could use a technique called “Principal component analysis (PCA)” to extract the most important features and then visualize them on a graph.

Instead, our model only has 3 features so we’ll visualize 2 of these for the movies and plot each movie based on the movie’s learned features. After plotting, we can interpret what each feature “could represent.”
Intuitively, movie feature 1 could be interpreted as drama vs. comedy and movie feature 3 could be viewed as “geared towards males” vs. “geared towards females.”
This isn’t perfect, but it’s a reasonable explanation. Warrior is more drama than comedy, but the others seem to make sense.

A movie rating can be broken down into a movie vector and a user vector. Once a person has rated just a few items (implicitly or explicitly), a recommender system will use the wisdom of the crowd and your ratings to predict other films you’ll likely enjoy. The size of the vectors (or “latent factors”) is determined through trial and error testing and is based on the size of your data set.
I encourage you to play around with the spreadsheets and see what happens as you change the model’s hyperparameters.
If you liked this and want to get more excellerated learnings and cheat sheets sent straight to your inbox, click below and enter your email (they’re all free).
Share with others and spread the joy of machine learning magic :)
Merging mankind with machine, 1 spreadsheet at a time https://www.ExcelwithML.com | Get AI-generated advice at https://mastermind.fyi/
